Chapter 3 of the Bodhisattva MahÄvairocana's Section on the Virtuous King of Great Brilliance
Furthermore, good sons!

Ordinary people, if they encounter physical or mental suffering, give rise to various evils. If they get a physical illness or a mental illness, they cause their body, speech, and mind to commit various evils.
Because of committing evil deeds, they transmigrate through the three paths and experience all kinds of suffering.
Why is it so?
Because ordinary people lack mindfulness and wisdom, they give rise to various defilements. This is called the defilement of mindfulness.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva always thinks like this:

'From countless eons in the past, I have created various evils with this body and mind. Because of these causes and conditions, I have been transmigrating in the cycle of birth and death, experiencing various sufferings in the three evil paths, and have thus been far from the right path of the three vehicles.
The bodhisattva, because of this evil cause and condition, gives rise to great fear in his own body and mind, abandons the multitude of evils, and heads towards the good path.
Good man!
It is like a king who puts four poisonous snakes in a box, and has a person raise, feed, care for, and wash their bodies.
'If I allow one snake to give rise to anger, I will punish him according to the law in the city.'
At that time, the person, hearing the king's strict order, was frightened and abandoned the box to flee.
The king then sent five caá¹‡á¸Älas with drawn swords to follow him.
The person looked back and saw the five people behind him, so he fled even faster.
At that time, the five people secretly hid the swords they were holding, and secretly sent one person who pretended to be a close friend, saying to him:
'You can come back.'
The person did not believe, and went to a village, wanting to hide himself.
Having entered the village, he looked into the houses but did not see any people. He took up various vessels but found nothing in them.
Not seeing anyone and unable to find anything, he sat down on the ground and heard a voice from the sky:
Alas, man!
This village is empty and desolate, without any inhabitants. Tonight, there will be six great thieves coming.
If you encounter them, your life will not be preserved.
How can you escape them?
At that time, the man's fear increased even more, so he left again.
On the way, he came across a river with swift-flowing waters, without any boats or rafts.
Out of fear, he gathered various grasses and wood to make a raft.
He further thought:
'If I stay here, I will be harmed by the poisonous snake, the five candÄlas, the one pretending to be friendly, and the six great thieves.
If I cross this river, the raft may not be reliable and I may drown to death.
It would rather die in the water than be harmed by snakes and thieves.
' Then, pushing the grass raft into the water, the body leaned on it, moving hands and feet to cut through the current and leave.
Having reached the other shore, safe and sound, the mind and thoughts were at ease, and fear and anxiety were eliminated.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who hear and uphold the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra contemplate the body as a box, and the four elements of earth, water, fire, and wind as four poisonous snakes - the poison of sight, the poison of touch, the poison of breath, and the poison of bite. All sentient beings encounter these four poisons and lose their lives.

The four elements of sentient beings are also like this. Either seeing is evil, or touching is evil, or breathing is evil, or biting is evil. For these reasons, they stay away from many wholesome things.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe the four poisonous snakes to have four kinds of clans, namely ká¹£atriya, brÄhmaá¹‡a, vaiÅ›ya, and Å›Å«dra.
These four poisonous snakes are also like this, having four kinds of natures:
solid nature, wet nature, hot nature, and moving nature.
Therefore, bodhisattvas observe these four elements to have the same nature as the four poisonous snakes.
Furthermore, good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe these four elements to be like four poisonous snakes.
What is observing?
These four poisonous snakes always seek an opportunity to strike a person, thinking, 'When will I look at them?ğŸ”½When will I touch them?
When will I exhale?
When will I bite them?'
The four poisonous snakes are also like this, always seeking an opportunity to harm sentient beings.ğŸ”½If one is killed by the four snakes, one will never end up in the three evil destinies;
If one is harmed by the four elements, one will definitely end up in the three evil destinies, without a doubt.
Although these four poisonous snakes are tended to, they still want to kill people;
The four elements are also like this. Although they are always taken care of, they always lead people to create various evils.
If one of these four poisonous snakes becomes angry, it can kill a person;
The nature of the four elements is also like this. If one element arises, it can also harm a person.
Although these four poisonous snakes are in the same place, their four minds are different;
The four poisonous snakes of the four elements are also like this. Although they are in the same place, their natures are each different.
Although these four poisonous snakes are respected, they are difficult to be close to;

The four poisonous snakes of the four elements are also like this. Although they are respected, they are also difficult to be close to.ğŸ”½If these four poisonous snakes harm a person, there may be Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others who can cure them with spells and medicine;
The four elements kill a person, and although there are Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others with divine spells and good medicine, they cannot cure it.
Just as a person who likes himself, upon smelling the foul and disgusting stench of the four poisonous snakes, will then stay far away from them;
The buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this. Upon smelling the stench of the four elements, they will then stay far away from them.
At that time, the bodhisattva further contemplates the four poisonous snakes of the four elements, giving rise to great fear, turning his back and running away, cultivating the eightfold noble path.
The five cÄá¹‡á¸Älas are precisely the five aggregates.
How does the bodhisattva contemplate the five aggregates as being like cÄá¹‡á¸Älas?
CÄá¹‡á¸Älas are always able to cause people to be separated from loved ones and to gather with those they dislike;
The five aggregates are also like this. They cause people to greedily approach unwholesome dharmas and to distance themselves from all pure and wholesome dharmas.
Furthermore, good man!
Just as cÄá¹‡á¸Älas adorn themselves with various weapons, such as swords, shields, bows, arrows, armor, and spears, which are able to harm people;
The five aggregates are also like this. With various afflictions, they firmly adorn themselves, harming foolish people and causing them to fall into various existences.
Good man!
It is like a chandala who can harm those who have transgressed;
The five aggregates are also like this. With the transgression of various bonds, they can always harm people.
Therefore, bodhisattvas deeply contemplate the five aggregates as being like chandalas.
Furthermore, bodhisattvas contemplate the five aggregates as being like chandalas.
Chandalas have no compassionate heart and harm both enemies and friends;
The five aggregates are also like this. They have no compassionate heart and harm both good and evil.
It is like how chandalas torment all people;
The five aggregates are also like this. With various afflictions, they always torment all sentient beings in the cycle of birth and death.
Therefore, bodhisattvas view the five aggregates as being like chandalas.
Furthermore, bodhisattvas contemplate the five aggregates as being like chandalas.
Chandalas always harbor malicious intentions;
The five aggregates are also like this, always harboring the mind of afflictions and harming others.
Just as a person without feet, a sword, or attendants will certainly be killed by a caá¹‡á¸Äla,
sentient beings are also like this. Without feet, without a sword, without attendants, they will be harmed by the five aggregates.
Feet are called precepts, a sword is called wisdom, and attendants are called good spiritual friends.
Without these three things, one will be harmed by the five aggregates.
Therefore, the bodhisattva views the five aggregates as caá¹‡á¸Älas.
Furthermore, good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva observes that the five aggregates are worse than caá¹‡á¸Älas.
Why is it so?
If sentient beings are killed by the five caá¹‡á¸Älas, they will not fall into hell;
But those killed by the aggregates will fall into hell.
For this reason, the bodhisattva views the aggregates as worse than caá¹‡á¸Älas.
Having made this observation, he makes the vow:
'I would rather be near a chandala until the end of my life, than be near the five aggregates even for a short while.
A chandala can only harm foolish people in the desire realm;
This thief of the five aggregates completely harms ordinary beings in the three realms.
A chandala only kills those who have committed offenses;
This thief of the five aggregates, regardless of whether beings have committed offenses or not, is able to harm them all.
A chandala does not harm the aged, women, or children;
This thief of the five aggregates does not ask whether beings are old, young, female, or weak, and harms them all.
' Therefore, the bodhisattva deeply observes that these aggregates are worse than a chandala. Therefore, he makes the vow:
'I would rather be near a chandala until the end of my life, than be near the five aggregates even for a short while.'
Furthermore, good man!
A chandala only harms others, never harming himself;
The five aggregates are thieves who harm themselves, harm others, and are like executioners.
Executioners can be bribed with kind words, money, and valuables to let one go;
the five aggregates are not like this, and one cannot bribe them with kind words, money, and valuables to let one go.
Executioners do not necessarily kill people all four seasons;
the five aggregates are not like this, and they always harm sentient beings in every thought.
Executioners are only in one place, and one can escape;
the five aggregates are not like this, they are everywhere, and there is no escape.
Even though executioners harm people, they do not follow after them when they have killed;
the five aggregates are not like this, they kill sentient beings and follow after them without leaving.
Therefore, bodhisattvas would rather be with executioners for their whole lives than be with the five aggregates for even a short time.
A wise person can use skillful means to escape the five aggregates.
Skillful means refers to the eightfold noble path, the six perfections, and the four immeasurable minds.
Through these skillful means, one attains liberation, and body and mind are not harmed by the five aggregates.
Why is this?
The body is like vajra, and the mind is like space. Therefore, body and mind are difficult to destroy.
For this reason, the bodhisattva observes that the aggregates accomplish various unwholesome dharmas, giving rise to great fear, and cultivates the eightfold noble path.
It is also like that person who is afraid of the four poisonous snakes and the five caá¹‡á¸Älas, and goes on the road without looking back.
The one who pretends to be a good friend is called craving and love.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva deeply observes the bonds of craving as being like an enemy pretending to be a friend.
If one knows the truth, then there is nothing that can be done;
if one is unable to know, then one will certainly be harmed.
Craving and love are also like this. If one knows its nature, then it is unable to cause sentient beings to revolve in the suffering of birth and death;
If one does not know this, one will transmigrate through the six destinies and experience all kinds of suffering.
Why is this so?
The illness of craving is difficult to abandon, like an enemy pretending to be a friend, which is hard to distance oneself from.
An enemy pretending to be a friend always seeks an opportunity to cause separation from those one loves and bring together those one dislikes.
Craving is also like this, causing one to distance oneself from all wholesome dharmas and approach all unwholesome dharmas.
For this reason, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas deeply contemplate craving as being like an enemy pretending to be a friend, because of seeing what is not seen and hearing what is not heard.
Like ordinary people who see the faults of birth and death, although they have wisdom, because of delusion they later see again;
ÅšrÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas are also like this, although they see they do not see, although they hear they do not hear.
Why is this so?
Because of the mind of craving.
Why is this so?
Because of seeing the faults of birth and death, one is unable to quickly attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
For this reason, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas view this fetter of craving as an enemy feigning friendship.
What is meant by the appearance of an enemy feigning friendship?
Like an enemy, it is not real, yet it feigns the appearance of reality;
it cannot be befriended, yet it feigns the appearance of being close;
it is actually unwholesome, yet it feigns the appearance of goodness;
it is actually unlovable, yet it feigns the appearance of love.
Why is this?
Because it always seeks an opportunity to harm people.

Craving is also like this. It always makes things unreal for sentient beings, feigns reality, feigns closeness when it is not close, feigns goodness when it is not good, and feigns love when it is not lovable. It always deceives all beings, causing them to revolve in birth and death.
For this reason, Bodhisattvas view craving as an enemy feigning friendship.
As for an enemy feigning friendship, one only sees its body and mouth, not its mind. Therefore, it can deceive.
Craving is also like this. It is only for empty deception. Its reality cannot be obtained. Therefore, it can confuse all sentient beings.
The enemy pretending to be a friend has a beginning and an end, and is easy to avoid;
Love is not like this, without beginning or end, and difficult to avoid.
The enemy pretending to be a friend, far away is difficult to perceive, close by is easy to know;
Love is not like this, close by is still difficult to know, let alone far away?
For this reason, the Bodhisattva sees love as worse than a pretending friend.
All sentient beings, because of the bonds of love, are far from great nirvana and close to birth and death;
Far from permanence, bliss, self, and purity, close to impermanence, suffering, no-self, and impurity.
Therefore, I have said in various sutras that they are the three defilements.
Regarding present matters, because of ignorance, one does not see the faults and cannot let go.
The enemy pretending to be a friend can never harm the wise.

Therefore, the bodhisattva deeply observes this craving and gives rise to great fear. Cultivating the eightfold noble path is like that person fearing the four poisonous snakes, five cÄá¹‡á¸Älas, and one false friend, and not looking back on the road.
An empty village refers to the six internal sense bases.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva observes these six sense bases to be empty and nonexistent, just like an empty village.
Just as that frightened person, having entered the village, does not see a single inhabitant, and searches everywhere but finds not a single thing,
the bodhisattva is also like this. Carefully observing the six sense bases to be empty and nonexistent, he does not see the reality of a single being or thing.
Therefore, the bodhisattva observes the six internal sense bases to be empty and nonexistent, like that empty village.
Good man!ğŸ”½That empty village, when seen from afar by a group of thieves, never gives rise to the thought of emptiness.
Ordinary beings are also like this. They do not give rise to the thought of emptiness regarding the six sense bases, which are like a village.
Because they are unable to give rise to the thought of emptiness, they revolve in birth and death, experiencing immeasurable suffering.
Good son!
When the bandits arrived, they gave rise to the thought of emptiness.
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Contemplating these six sense bases, they always give rise to the thought of emptiness;
Giving rise to the thought of emptiness, they do not revolve in birth and death, experiencing suffering.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are always without error regarding these six sense bases;
Because they are without error, they do not revolve in birth and death.
Furthermore, good son!
It is like a group of bandits entering this empty village and then attaining peace and happiness;
The bandits of afflictions are also like this. Entering these six sense bases, they attain peace and happiness.
Just as bandits dwelling in an empty village have nothing to fear;
The bandits of afflictions are also like this. Dwelling in these six sense bases, they also have nothing to fear.
Just as that empty village is the dwelling place of lions, tigers, wolves, and various evil beasts;
The six internal sense bases are also like this, as they are the dwelling places of all evil afflictions and vicious beasts.
Therefore, the bodhisattva deeply observes that the six sense bases are empty and nonexistent, and are purely the dwelling places of all that is unwholesome.
Furthermore, good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva observes that the six internal sense bases are empty and nonexistent, like that empty village.
Why is it so?

Because of being false and unreal, having the notion of existence when empty and nonexistent, having the notion of pleasure when there is actually no pleasure, and having the notion of a person when there is actually no person.

The six internal sense bases are also like this, having the notion of existence when empty and nonexistent, having the notion of pleasure when there is actually no pleasure, and having the notion of a person when there is actually no person. Only a wise person can know this and attain its true reality.
Furthermore, good man!
Like an empty village, sometimes there are people and sometimes there are no people.
The six sense bases are not like this, they are always empty.
Why is it so?
Because their nature is always empty, it is known by the wise, not seen by the eyes.

Therefore, the Bodhisattva observes that the internal six sense bases have many enemies and harms, cultivates the Eightfold Noble Path, does not rest, just like that person who is afraid of the four poisonous snakes, the five CÄá¹‡á¸Äla, the one pretending to be kind, and the six great thieves, and in fear, takes the right path.
The six great thieves are the external six sense objects.
The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva observes these six sense objects as the six great thieves.
Why is it so?
Because they can plunder all wholesome dharmas.
Just as the six great thieves can plunder the wealth and treasures of all the people;
These six sense object thieves are also like this, they can plunder the wholesome wealth of all sentient beings.

Just as the six great thieves, if they enter someone's house, can plunder all the current possessions of the household, not discriminating between good and bad, causing the very wealthy to suddenly become poor.
The six sense objects are also like this. If they enter one's faculties, they can plunder all wholesome dharmas;
When wholesome dharmas are exhausted, one becomes poor, solitary, and a icchantika.
Therefore, bodhisattvas contemplate the six sense objects as if they were six great thieves.
Moreover, good man!
When the six great thieves want to rob people, they must rely on insiders. If there are no insiders, they will retreat.

The six sense objects are also like this. They want to plunder wholesome dharmas, but they must rely on the existence of the characteristics of sentient beings, knowledge, permanence, bliss, self, purity, non-emptiness, and so forth within.
If there are no such characteristics within, the evil thieves of the six sense objects will not be able to plunder all wholesome dharmas.
The wise have no such characteristics within, but ordinary beings do.
Therefore, the six sense objects always come to encroach upon and plunder the wealth of wholesome dharmas.
Because they are not well protected, they are robbed by them.
Protection is called wisdom. A wise person can skillfully protect and thus is not robbed.
Therefore, bodhisattvas view these six sense objects as the same as the six great thieves, without distinction.
Furthermore, good man!
Like the six great thieves who can cause people's bodies and minds to suffer;
These six sense object thieves are also like this, always causing sentient beings' bodies and minds to suffer.
The six great thieves can only rob people's present wealth;
These six sense object thieves always rob sentient beings' wholesome wealth of the three times.
The six great thieves rejoice at night;
The six sense object thieves are also like this, finding joy in dwelling in the darkness of ignorance.
The six great thieves can only be stopped by the kings;
The six sense object thieves are also like this, only Buddhas and bodhisattvas can stop them.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
These six great thieves, when they want to rob, do not discriminate between handsome and ugly, noble and lowly, intelligent and ignorant, well-educated and uncultured, wealthy and poor.
The six sense objects are also like this. When they want to rob wholesome dharmas, they do not discriminate between handsome and ugly, up to poor and lowly.
Although the kings of these six great thieves cut off their hands and feet, they still cannot make their minds stop.
The six sense objects are also like this. Although srota-Äpannas, saká¹›d-ÄgÄmins, and anÄgÄmins cut off their hands and feet, they still cannot make them not rob wholesome dharmas.
It is like a brave and strong person who is able to subdue these six great thieves;
The buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this. They are able to subdue the six sense objects, which are like evil thieves.
It is like a person who has many relatives and a prosperous clan. They are not robbed by those six thieves;
Beings are also like this. If they have good spiritual friends, they are not robbed by the six sense objects, which are like evil thieves.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
These six great thieves, if they see people and things, are able to steal and rob;
The six sense objects are not like this, if seen, known, heard, smelled, touched, or perceived, they are all able to rob.
The six great thieves are only able to plunder the wealth of people in the desire realm, and are unable to plunder the form and formless realms;
The evil thieves of the six sense objects are not like this, they are able to plunder all the good treasures of the three realms.
Therefore, the bodhisattva contemplates the six sense objects as being worse than those six thieves.

Having made this contemplation, he cultivates the eightfold noble path, going straight forward without turning back, like that frightened person who fears the four poisonous snakes, the five cÄá¹‡á¸Äla, the one pretending to be kind, and the six great thieves, abandoning the empty village and going on the road.
The road encountering a river is the afflictions.
How does the bodhisattva contemplate these afflictions as being like a great river?
Like that swift river which is able to carry away even a fragrant elephant;
The swift river of afflictions is also like this, able to carry away the pratyekabuddhas.
Therefore, the bodhisattva deeply observes the afflictions to be like a swift river.
It is difficult to reach the bottom, so it is called a river;
The edge cannot be found, so it is called great, and there are many kinds of evil fish in it.
The great river of afflictions is also like this. Only the Buddha and bodhisattvas can reach the bottom, so it is called extremely deep;
Only the Buddha and bodhisattvas can find its edge, so it is called vast;
It always harms all foolish beings, so it is called evil fish.
Therefore, the bodhisattva observes these afflictions to be like a great river.
Just as the water of a great river can nourish all grasses, trees, and forests;
The great river of afflictions is also like this, able to nourish beings in the twenty-five existences.
Therefore, the bodhisattva observes these afflictions to be like a great river.
It is like a person who falls into a great river and has no shame or remorse;
Sentient beings are also like this, falling into the river of afflictions without shame or remorse.
Like one who falls into a river, if one does not reach the bottom, one will immediately lose one's life;
Falling into the river of afflictions is also like this, not reaching the bottom, one revolves and transmigrates through the twenty-five forms of existence.
What is called the bottom is called the mark of emptiness.
If there are those who do not cultivate such an empty mark, one should know that such a person cannot escape the twenty-five forms of existence.
Because all sentient beings are not able to skillfully cultivate emptiness and the markless, they are always swept away by the swift river of afflictions.
Like that great river, it can only destroy the body and cannot sweep away all wholesome dharmas;
The great river of afflictions is not like this, it can destroy all wholesome dharmas of body and mind.
That great violent river can only sweep away people in the desire realm;
The great river of afflictions can sweep away humans and gods in the three realms.
The great rivers of the world, if one moves one's hands and feet, one can reach the other shore;
The great river of afflictions can only be crossed by bodhisattvas through the six perfections.
Just as the great river's waters are difficult to cross;
The great river of afflictions is also like this, difficult to cross.
What is meant by difficult to cross?
Even the great bodhisattvas of the ten abodes are still unable to ultimately cross it. Only the buddhas are able to ultimately cross it, and therefore it is called difficult to cross.
It is like a person being carried away by a river, unable to cultivate even the slightest wholesome dharma;
Sentient beings are also like this. Those who are carried away and submerged by the river of afflictions are also unable to cultivate wholesome dharmas.
It is like a person falling into a river and being carried away by the water. Others who are strong are able to rescue them;
But those who fall into the river of afflictions and become icchantikas cannot be rescued by Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, or even the buddhas.
When the great rivers of the world are at the end of the eon, the seven suns shine together and are able to cause them to dry up;
The great river of afflictions is not like this. Even if Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas cultivate the seven factors of enlightenment, they still cannot dry it up.
Therefore, bodhisattvas view the afflictions as a violent river.

It is like that person who was afraid of the four poisonous snakes, the five cÄá¹‡á¸Äla, the one feigning kindness, and the six great thieves, leaving the empty village and following the road. Having reached the river bank, he gathered grass to make a raft.

The bodhisattva is also like this. Afraid of the four great snakes, the five skandhas' cÄá¹‡á¸Äla, the feigning kindness of craving, the empty village of the six sense bases, and the evil thieves of the six sense objects, he reaches the river of afflictions and cultivates precepts, concentration, wisdom, liberation, the knowledge and insight of liberation, the six pÄramitÄs, and the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment as a raft. Relying on this raft, he crosses the river of afflictions and reaches the other shore of the eternal, blissful, and nirvÄá¹‡a.
The bodhisattva who practices the great nirvÄá¹‡a thinks like this:
'If I cannot endure such physical suffering and mental suffering, then I will not be able to enable all sentient beings to cross the river of afflictions.'
Thinking like this, although there is such physical and mental suffering and distress, he silently endures it.
Because of enduring it, he does not give rise to defilements.
The Bodhisattva is like this, yet he still has no defilements, let alone the Buddha, the TathÄgata, who would have defilements?
Therefore, the Buddhas are not called defiled.
Why is the TathÄgata not without defilements?
Because the TathÄgata always practices within the defiled, and the defiled are precisely the twenty-five forms of existence.
Therefore, the Å›rÄvakas and ordinary people say that the Buddha has defilements, but the Buddhas, the TathÄgatas, are truly without defilements.
Good man!
For this reason, the Buddhas, the TathÄgatas, have no fixed characteristics.
Good man!
Therefore, the one who commits the four grave offenses, slanders the Vaipulya sÅ«tras, and the icchantika are all not fixed.
At that time, the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva MahÄvairocana-abhyudgata-rÄja said:
It is just as you have said, O Holy One.
All dharmas are not fixed, and because they are not fixed, we should know that the TathÄgata also does not ultimately enter nirvÄá¹‡a.
As the Buddha has previously said:
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who cultivate the great nirvÄá¹‡a hear of nirvÄá¹‡a and great nirvÄá¹‡a, whether they hear it or not.
What is nirvÄá¹‡a?
What is great nirvÄá¹‡a?
At that time, the Buddha praised the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva MahÄvairocana-abhyudgata-rÄja, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
If there are bodhisattvas who attain mindfulness and dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, they will be able to ask questions like you have.
Good man!
It is like worldly people saying:

There are seas and great seas, rivers and great rivers, mountains and great mountains, earth and great earth, cities and great cities, beings and great beings, kings and great kings, people and great people, gods and gods among gods, paths and great paths;
Nirvana is also like this, with nirvana and great nirvana.
What is nirvana?
Good man!
Like a hungry person who obtains a little food and drink and is called peaceful and happy, this kind of peace and happiness is also called nirvana;
Like a sick person who recovers and is called peaceful and happy, this kind of peace and happiness is also called nirvana;
Like a person who is afraid and finds a place to take refuge and thus obtains peace and happiness, this kind of peace and happiness is also called nirvana;
Like a poor person who obtains the seven treasures and thus obtains peace and happiness, this kind of peace and happiness is also called nirvana;
Just as when a person contemplates a skeleton and does not give rise to desire, they attain peace and happiness. Such peace and happiness is also called nirvÄá¹‡a.
However, such nirvÄá¹‡a cannot be called great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Why is it so?
Because of hunger and thirst, illness, fear, poverty, and attachment, it is called nirvÄá¹‡a, but not great nirvÄá¹‡a.
